ph_descripcion:
By our NatGeo Photographer @massimobassano on assignment in the Atlantic Ocean.
***
‚ÄúFalkland is our first immersion into wildlife of this epic journey‚Äù ‚Äì tells Massimo ‚Äì ‚Äúin front of us, two rock shags (Leucocarbo magellanicus), also known as the Magellanic cormorant, make a kind of love dance. The shag is a marine cormorant found around the southernmost coasts of South America till the Falkland Islands. The rock shag usually nests on ledges on steep, bare, rocky cliffs, but today we are lucky to see them acting their love approach on the small pier of Carcass Island. Just in front of us, our cameras and smartphone‚Äù.
***
Follow NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignments for National Geographic Expeditions along the most remote places of the Atlantic Ocean.
***

ph_descripcion:
By our NatGeo Photographer @massimobassano on assignment in the Atlantic Ocean.
***
‚ÄúA juvenile of black crowned night heron, with his distinctive orange eye, welcomes us on our landing at Carcass island, in the northwest side of the Falkland‚Äù ‚Äì tells Massimo ‚Äì ‚Äúit‚Äôs quite a common species with four subspecies and one of these four is endemic here in the Falkland. Widely observed by the German ornithologist Ernst Johann Otto Hartert who published a long study in 1914. Here at the Falkland is known with the nickname of Quark. He is quietly waiting the low tide so to start banqueting the small fish, leeches, earthworms, mussels, crustaceans and any other amphibians left by the ocean that retreats cyclically‚Äù.
***
Follow NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignments for National Geographic Expeditions along the most remote places of the Atlantic Ocean.
***

ph_descripcion:
By our NatGeo Photographer @massimobassano on assignment in the Atlantic Ocean.
***
‚ÄúNew Island is our first stop in the Falkland‚Äù ‚Äì tells Massimo ‚Äì ‚Äúafter a full day at sea, we are very excited to touch our first land of this epic voyage. This island is an example of virtuous conservation. Since 1995, the New Island Conservation Trust is taking care of this island. The NICT is made by the same people that live on the island that decided to preserve the biodiversity of their place and opening to a sustainable tourism. We cleaned and disinfected all our boots to be sure that while walking here we don‚Äôt bring any pest that can damage the local environment. And the result of our dedication are the view of a chick of Black-Browed Albatross waiting to be fed by his parent. Among many many other birds. Over forty different of bird species found home here in New Island. A joy for the eyes and for photography‚Äù.
***
Follow NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignments for National Geographic Expeditions along the most remote places of the Atlantic Ocean.
***

ph_descripcion:
By our NatGeo Photographer @massimobassano on assignment along the Atlantic Ocean.
‚ÄúThe EPIC VOYAGE started. Our ship #NationalGeographicExplorer left the dock of Ushuaia, one of the southernmost towns of the world. It is sailing to the Falkland/Malvinas where we will touch our first land by tomorrow morning‚Äù ‚Äì says Massimo ‚Äì ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just the beginning of an incredible journey all along the Atlantic Ocean, from Patagonia to Madeira, exploring some of the most remote places on Earth. It really is an expedition of lifetime‚Äù.
The handmade map shows the itinerary of this Atlantic Isles Discovery‚Ä¶with many discoveries on the way.
***
Follow NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignments for National Geographic Expeditions along the most remote places of the Atlantic Ocean.
***

ph_descripcion:
Photographs by @massimobassano National Geographic photographer.
***
Just announced: ‚ÄúA hidden corridor has been found inside the Khufu‚Äôs Pyramid. Could it bring us to new discoveries?‚Äù
‚ÄúAny announcement about the Egyptians‚Äù ‚Äì tell Massimo, our Nat Geo photographer ‚Äì ‚Äúmakes me jump off my seat. I know that Archeology is a slow process, and many more things can be discovered but nothing as Egypt, can excite my fantasy and desire of knowing more and more. National Geographic has many expeditions to Egypt. With the most expert local guides, this trip is a pure immersion to the Egyptian civilization. Whatever I know, I still learn so much every time I go there. I can‚Äôt wait to go there next November‚Äù.
The Great Pyramid is one of the largest stone structures, and archeological monument, in the world. Built 4500 years ago by the king Khufu (Cheops), on the Giza plateau (today named Giza Complex) on the southwest side of Cairo, the pyramid is 139 m high and 230 m wide. Its weight is estimated at 7 million tons.
‚ÄúTaking a photograph of the great pyramid, has more sense including in the frame the view of the Sphinx, such a recognizable monument‚Äù ‚Äì recommend Massimo ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe Great Sphinx of Giza is a limestone statue of a reclining sphinx, a mythical creature with the head of a human, and the body of a lion. The Sphinx has stimulated the fantasy of many of us for years and years. Khufu and the Sphinx, a great combination‚Äù.
***
Follow NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignments for National Geographic around the World
***

ph_descripcion:
Follow NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignments for National Geographic around the World
***
‚ÄúIn Egyptian hieroglyphs, a cartouche is an oval with a line at one end tangent to it, indicating that the text enclosed is a royal name. The first examples of the cartouche are associated with pharaohs at the end of the Third Dynasty, but the feature did not come into common use until the beginning of the Fourth Dynasty under Pharaoh Sneferu‚Äù ‚Äì the clear voice of our guide, Fatma Abdalla, is enriching our knowledge again. This what she does all day long leading us around the magnificence of the Egyptian temples in this incredible expedition named, not casually, Ancient wonders of the legendary Nile. We are exploring the most incredible sites sailing along the most famous river of the antiquity. As the Egyptians did for thousands of years. ‚ÄúAs a hieroglyph, a cartouche can represent the Egyptian-language word for "name" ‚Äì keep saying Fatma ‚Äì ‚Äúthis is Ksrs nty khu, the venerable Caesar, so we are talking when the Romans came to Egypt, with Julius Caesar‚Äù.
***

ph_descripcion:
Follow NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignments for National Geographic around the World
***
‚ÄúVisiting Egypt is one of the most fascinating expeditions of all time‚Äù ‚Äì says Massimo, National Geographic photographer ‚Äì ‚ÄúComing here for me, it‚Äôs a dream that comes true. And I came multiple times already, but it‚Äôs always like the first time. I‚Äôm never tired to admire the pyramids complex of Giza. It‚Äôs a view that fill the eyes, the heart, the soul. the grandeur of the Egyptians has passed the millennia, reaching us thanks to the passion of hundreds of archaeologists from all over the world. Many are those who have dug here thanks to the National Geographic grants. For that, it's a bit like coming home for me".
***

ph_descripcion:
Photos by @nickcobbing

Staying up to watch the midnight sun in Antarctica. These three pictures were made around 11:30 pm from the deck of the National Geographic Resolution. I really needed to sleep but had to keep checking! These images were taken 12 mins apart as the light changed, we were near the north entrance to the Lemaire Channel.

#sunset #sunsetlovers #nightphotography #antarctica #lemairechannel #landscapephotography
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions on January 31, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Image by @SergioPitamitz / Emperor penguins pair on sea ice, Larsen B Ice Shelf, Weddell Sea, Antarctica.
Emperor penguins are considered near threatened on IUCN Red List of Threatened Species and their populations are expected to decline rapidly in years to come. On average they measure 120cm tall and they are the largest of all the different kinds of penguin.
Shot on assignment in the Weddell Sea, Antarctica, for @NatGeoExpeditions
Please join @SergioPitamitz for more images from his National Geographic Assignments.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
#Antarctica #penguin #emperorpenguin #conservation #wildlifephotography #onassignment #TravelwithNatGeo #NatGeoExpeditions #NationalGeographicExpeditions
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions on January 23, 2023.

ph_descripcion: photograph by @susanseubert // A chinstrap penguin on Half Moon Island off of the Antarctic Peninsula appears to be dancing, when in reality, this bird is about to do a faceplant. Penguins do not have teeth. They have a sharp beak that helps to grab and hold onto the fish, but they cannot chew. So they have to swallow all of their fish completely whole! If you look inside their mouth, they do have barbs on their tongue and roof of their mouth that help to swallow the fish. Photographed #onassignment for @natgeo @natgeotravel @natgeoexpeditions #worldpenguinawarenessday #Antarctica #HalfMoonIsland Follow @susanseubert for more as she heads to Antarctica next week!
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions in Half Moon Island, Antarctic Peninsula.

ph_descripcion:
Photo by @nickcobbing

A Weddell seal resting on a bank of snow in Antarctica. A member of the 'true seal' family, Weddells are fairly abundant in the Antarctic region. They are well adapted to a sea ice environment, feeding under ice (diving up to 350 -500 metres) and raising their young above sea ice. They have this beautifully mottled fur and are known for their unique vocalisations.

Photographed during our recent expedition aboard the @natgeo Resolution ship. This photo is made from some distance using a telephoto lens, plus a big crop to show more detail.

#wildlifephotography #nature #antartica #sealsofinstagram
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions on January 18, 2023.

This picture was made at Tiritiri Matangi, a pest free island that is an open sanctuary that anyone may visit and is reachable by ferry service from Auckland. Photographed #onassignment for @natgeoexpeditions @natgeo @natgeotravel #newzealand #keker≈´ #wildbirds #travel #tiritirimatangiisland
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions in Tiritiri Matangi Island, Auckland.

ph_descripcion: photograph by @susanseubert // Happy New Year from the caves at Waitomo on the North Island of New Zealand! We rang in 2023 with the glow worms as our fireworks. These are actually fungus gnats endemic to this area. They dwell in caves with high humidity and produce a blue-green bioluminescence. Photographed #onassignment for @natgeoexpeditions @natgeotravel #glowworms #newzealand #wiatomo #newzealand
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions in Waitomo Caves, New Zealand.

ph_descripcion:
Follow the NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignment for National Geographic around the World
‚ÄúLocals welcome us playing the panpipes, named Galevu in local language‚Äù ‚Äì tells Massimo ‚Äì ‚Äúeverywhere we land in the Solomon, we get a warm welcome from the locals. And every stop has a different welcome, dance, music. We are never tired to explore Melanesia‚Äù.
***
#natgeo #natgeoadventure #natgeotravel #natgeoinspires #solomonislands #natgeowild #exploration #natgeophotographer #pacificislands #melanesia #owaraha #music #flute #panpipes @lindbladexpeditions
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions on January 05, 2023.

ph_descripcion:
Follow NatGeo photographer @massimobassano on assignments for National Geographic around the World
‚ÄúTwo sail-pirogues cross the small bay at Utupua island. Even if the Vanuatu‚Äôs have access to boats with outboard engines, using the pirogue with sail or without is still the most popular way to move from place to place. Especially along the same island visiting the different communities‚Äù ‚Äì tells Massimo ‚Äì ‚ÄúSailing is my main passion and I‚Äôve done since my childhood. So, I‚Äôve lots of admiration for people that for thousands of years have been crossing the Pacific Ocean, island to island on large distance, with no one of the technology that we have been using since the middle age like the compass, for example, or just sketching maps. We have seen many pirogues during our expeditions in Melanesia and kids start to use one in very young age‚Äù.
***
#natgeo #natgeoadventure #natgeotravel #natgeoinspires #vanuatu #natgeowild #exploration #natgeophotographer #pacificislands #melanesia #utupua #silhouette #pirogue @lindbladexpeditions
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions on December 23, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Follow the NatGeo photographer @massimobassano and his assignments for National Geographic around the World.
‚ÄúChief Bong came from the village of Olal, located on the mountain slopes of Ambrym island, with a small group of his devotees to show us the most important dance of his community, the Rom Kon Dance‚Äù ‚Äì tell Massimo, our Nat Geo photographer ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe Rom Kon ceremony is performed by male secret society members to the beat of drums and seed shakers. Beside the wood mask, the remainder of the costume is composed of dried banana leaves, and each Rom dancer holds a wooden carving that symbolically represents a weapon. The Rom dancers themselves represent evil spirits who form a wide circle filled by Namba dancers. The participants sing songs and chant stories as they dance. Rom masks invoke the spirit of ancestors (generally the grandfather) and are important agents of social control. The masks and costumes must be destroyed or disposed of after a dance to ensure the spirit does not haunt the owner".
***
#natgeo #natgeoadventure #natgeotravel #natgeoinspires #vanuatu #natgeowild #natgeophotographer #pacificislands #melanesia #ambrym #rondance @lindbladexpeditions
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions on December 23, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photographs by @massimobassano on assignment in Melanesia.
‚ÄúAfter a day full of emotions and experiences, watching a tribal dance, tasting local food and admiring the beauty of the simplicity of people leaving on remote island of Melanesia, you can think that for today you have had all you were looking for‚Ä¶and beyond. But it‚Äôs when the sun is saying goodbye that you understand that an expedition in the Pacific has something to offer till the last second of light‚Äù.
Please follow @massimobassano and his assignments for National Geographic around the World
***

ph_descripcion:
Photographs by @massimobassano on assignment in Melanesia.
‚ÄúIn one frame, the whole story is told‚Äù ‚Äì says Massimo our NatGeo Expert ‚Äì ‚Äúwe are at Nendo Island, in the Solomon, and in one photograph I‚Äôm able to tell the full story of today. Dancers are ready to welcome us through their ritual dance. Their skin is covered with a layer of local soil to represent the link with Mother Earth. Flowers to get power from Nature. A smartphone shows that modernity is everywhere and useful to everybody. But it‚Äôs still pandemic time and an old lady wear a facemask‚Äù.
‚ÄúAs we all do‚Äù ‚Äì confirm Massimo ‚Äì ‚ÄúThese people have not seen tourists for two years. We are their main business but we have to respect their health over any other consideration. They live in isolate islands with small access to health facilities. Respecting them is our way to say thanks for welcoming us‚Äù.

ph_descripcion:
Photographs by @massimobassano on assignment in Melanesia.
‚ÄúOne of the most exclusive things we can discover during our expedition in the Solomon‚Äôs‚Äù ‚Äì tells Massimo our NatGeo Expert ‚Äì ‚Äúit‚Äôs their concept of currency, based on natural things that were available on the islands in the past. As this money coil, locally named tevau, on the head of the woman‚Äù.
‚ÄúIt can be up to 30feet long, covered with red feathers, taken from birds but respecting their body, leaving them alive and able to fly again because they primarily respect Nature‚Äù ‚Äì keep telling Massimo ‚Äì ‚Äúand it was a ceremonial currency particularly at marriages. Tevau were made exclusively on Ndende Island by hereditary specialists, whose skills were believed to come from spirits. Not made anymore, it's now an historical artifact of Melanesia. Traveling in Melanesia is a deep dive into traditions. Even a public show like this one, made for visitors like us, it‚Äôs full of meanings and we learn something new every day. My respect for this population rises day by day‚Äù.

Please follow him @massimobassano and his assignments for National Geographic around the World
#natgeo #natgeoadventure #natgeoinspires #solomonislands #natgeowild #natgeophotographer #pacificislands #melanesia #tevau

ph_descripcion:
Photo by Kike Calvo @kikeo ¬®There are times when we arrive at places that look magical,¬® said Kike. ¬®Guna Yala, an autonomous indigenous territory, is one of those hidden paradises. This remote island is Anmardub. The islands were known as San Blas, and later Kuna Yala, but in 2011 the Government of Panama recognized the claim that Guna Yala was a closer representation of the original name."

Please join @kikeo for images and stories from his National Geographic Assignments.

#gunayala #guna #natgeoexpeditions #nationalgeographicexpeditions #kikecalvo
ph_atributos: Photo by Nat Geo Expeditions on November 26, 2022.

ph_descripcion:
Photograph by @massimobassano on assignment in Melanesia.
Our exploration of the Solomon islands begins and a group of warriors of the Island of Santa Ana, also known as Owaraha, gives to us an "aggressive" welcome when we land on their island. Totally peaceful and warm people, they used to defend their territory by other tribes. So, they want to show us what they can do against any enemy. But we come in peace and so we are welcomed by them.
"I'm back to Melanesia after several years" - tells Massimo, our NatGeo expert on board the ship - "and I immediately feel as back at home after a long journey. I vividly remember when I drop the anchor of my sailboat in this island and I asked hospitality at these people. I was exhausted for the long Pacific crossing, and they took care of me as I was part of their family. Being in this expedition is really a bless for me".
Please follow him @massimobassano and his assignments for National Geographic around the World
#natgeo #natgeoadventure #natgeoinspires #solomonislands #natgeowild #natgeophotographer #pacificislands #melanesia

ph_descripcion:
Gentoo Penguins in Port Lockroy. A former British Research Station until 1962, is a United Kingdom Antarctic Heritage Trust museum and post office. Closed for the Covid-19 pandemic until October 2022, now the base is run by a team of four women.
Image by National Geographic Photographer Sergio Pitamitz @SergioPitamitz, currently in Antarctica on assignment for @NatGeoExpeditions.
